Definition: Focuses only on observable behavior and ignores internal mental states.
Exam Trap/Note: Behavior is shaped by environment, not heredity

Definition: Learning through association where a neutral stimulus triggers a response after pairing.
Example/Application: Bell (neutral) becomes Conditioned Stimulus (CS) after pairing with food (UCS)

Definition: Stimulus that naturally triggers a response without learning
Example/Application: Food, loud noise, puff of air

Definition: Previously neutral stimulus that now triggers a reaction
Example/Application: The bell (after pairing with food), Teacher's face (if associated with yelling)

Definition: Responding to stimuli similar to the conditioned stimulus
Example/Application: Fear of all dogs after being bitten by one

Definition: Weakening of the conditioned response when the CS is presented without the UCS
Example/Application: Teacher stops giving quizzes after bell ring; anxiety fades

Definition: Learning where voluntary behavior is strengthened or weakened by consequences
Example/Application: Student studies to get a grade (reinforcer)

Definition: Behaviors followed by favorable consequences are more likely to happen again
Example/Application: Cat in puzzle box learns to press lever for food

Definition: Adding a pleasant stimulus to INCREASE behavior
Removing an unpleasant stimulus to INCREASE behavior
Example/Application: Doing homework to stop parents form nagging; Seatbelt to stop beeping
Exam Trap/Note: Often confused with Punishment. Reinforcement always INCREASES behavior.

Definition: Adding an unpleasant stimulus to DECREASE behavior
Removing a pleasant stimulus to DECREASE behavior

Example/Application: Giving a sticker for every correct math problem

Definition: Reward after a set number of responses
Exam Trap/Note: High response rate with pause after reward

Definition: Reward after an unpredictable number of responses
Example/Application: Slot machines, calling on students randomly
Exam Trap/Note: Most resistant to extinction; high steady rate

Definition: Reward for first response after a set time period
Reinforcing successive approximations toward a target goal
Example/Application: Rewarding holding pencil -> touching paper -> drawing line
Exam Trap/Note: Used when student cannot perform task at all yet

Definition: Using a high-frequency (preferred) activity to reinforce a low-frequency task
Example/Application: "First do your math, then you can play games"

Definition: System using tokens (secondary reinforcers) exchanged for backup reinforcers
Exam Trap/Note: Effective in special education and clinical settings

Definition: Encouraging a behavior until the student gets tired of it
Example/Application: Letting a student throw spitballs until they are sick of it
Requires Attention and Perception to move info forward

Definition: Workbench of the mind; conscious processing
Grouping bits of info into larger meaningful units
Example/Application: Grouping 1-9-8-4 into "1984" to remember a date
Knowing 2+2=4 or the capital of France

Definition: Memory of how to perform tasks (muscle memory)
Knowledge about one's own thinking processes (Planning, Monitoring, Evaluation)
Example/Application: Asking "Do I understand this?" while reading

Definition: Old information blocks recall of new information
Example/Application: Can't learn new phone number because old one pops up

Definition: New information wipes out/blocks old information
Example/Application: Learning Spanish makes you forget your French

Definition: Tendency to remember the beginning (Primacy) and end (Recency) of a list
Example/Application: Forgetting the middle part of a lecture

Definition: General rule of thumb or mental shortcut
Inability to use an object for a new function
Example/Application: Not realizing a shoe can be used as a hammer
Driving on right (US) hinders driving on left (UK)

Definition: Better recall when retrieval context matches learning context
Example/Application: Taking test in same seat you studied in

Definition: Information is stored better if represented both visually and verbally
We perceive patterns and wholes, not just parts

Example/Application: Object Permanence (objects exist when unseen); Learning through senses
Symbolic thought; Egocentrism (can't see others' view); No conservation yet
Exam Trap/Note: Child thinks tall glass has "more" water

Example/Application: Conservation achieved; Logical thinking about concrete objects; Seriation
Changing existing schema to fit new info (Zebra is not a horse)
Fitting new info into existing schema (Calling a zebra a "horse")
Gap between what learner can do alone and what they can do with help
Temporary support (clues, modeling) removed as ability increases
Children talking to self; viewed as self-regulation (unlike Piaget's egocentrism)

Exam Trap/Note: One is a Bun (Rust colored bun = T-rust)

Example/Application: Can I do things myself? (Toilet training)
Exam Trap/Note: Two is a Shoe (Auto in a shoe = Autonomy)

Example/Application: Is it okay for me to act/move? (Play)
Exam Trap/Note: Three is a Tree (Quilt on tree = Guilt)

Example/Application: Can I make it in the world? Competence in schoolwork is critical.
Exam Trap/Note: Four is a Dinosaur (Dusty dinosaur = In-dust-ry)

Example/Application: Who am I? Peer relationships dominant.

Exam Trap/Note: Six is Sticks (Two sticks in love)

Example/Application: Reflection on life; fulfillment or regret
Exam Trap/Note: Eight is a Plate (Grits on plate = Inte-grit-y)

Example/Application: Obedience for avoidance of punishment or for self-interest reward
Good Boy/Girl (social approval) and Law & Order (maintaining social rules)
Social Contract (unjust laws can change) and Universal Ethics
Proposed women's morality centers on relationships/care, not just justice
Commitment without exploration (Accepting parents' values blindly)

Key Figure: Doing activity for its own sake (curiosity, enjoyment)
Example/Application: Don't reward if they already love it (Overjustification)

Key Figure: Doing activity for reward or to avoid punishment
Internal (I control it) vs External (Teacher controls it)
Belief that failure is inevitable due to Internal + Stable + Uncontrollable factors
Example/Application: Student says "I'm just stupid" and quits

Key Figure: Belief in capability to execute a SPECIFIC task
Focus on learning and improvement; errors are part of learning
Focus on grades, looking good, beating others
Example/Application: Avoidance of challenging tasks to protect ego

Key Figure: Physiological, Safety, Belonging, Esteem (Must be met first)
Desire to set challenging goals and persist
Discomfort when beliefs and actions conflict
Motivation = Expectancy of success x Value of goal
Example/Application: If either is zero, motivation is zero

Key Figure: General intelligence factor underlying all abilities
Example/Application: Good at math = likely good at reading

Key Figure: 8 independent types (Linguistic, Musical, Spatial, Kinesthetic, etc.)
Perceives patterns as whole; socially oriented
Federal law guaranteeing Free Appropriate Public Education (FAPE)
Educate with non-disabled peers to max extent appropriate
Legal document outlining goals/services for qualifying disability
Civil rights law for accommodations (no specialized instruction needed)
Example/Application: ADHD or Diabetes needing extra time/snacks

Key Figure: Assessing DURING instruction to guide teaching (Low stakes)
Assessing AFTER instruction to judge mastery (High stakes)

Example/Application: Driver's license test, Mastery of objective
Scale gives same weight every time

Key Figure: Does it measure what it claims to?
Example/Application: Math test shouldn't test reading ability
Best when there are extreme outliers

Key Figure: How much scores vary from the mean (Spread)
Percentage of people scoring AT or BELOW a given score
Score represents performance of average student at that grade level
Example/Application: 5.2 = 5th grader month 2 (Trap: doesn't mean ready for 5th grade)
Review -> Present -> Guided Practice -> Independent Practice

Key Figure: Students figure out rules themselves; Constructivist
Intro framework given BEFORE lesson to connect to prior knowledge
Each student is 'expert' on one part and teaches group
"Eyes in back of head"; knowing what is happening everywhere

Example/Application: Helping group while signaling quiet to another
"I like how Sarah is sitting quietly"

Key Figure: Studying different age groups at same time
